message: I've laid out my few thoughts on this subject in my blog.  http://thedeterminedengineer.wordpress.com/
Very cool @SeanKnudsen.  I especially like the stuff about cut-and-paste engineering.  Reposting here.  http://embeddedgurus.com/area-0x51/2010/09/cut-and-paste-engineering/
Do we have an obligation to keep code maintainable for the future's techno-archivists?
It seems like the importance of legacy code will only code will only grow over time. (COR: Computers are relatively young so not much legacy code exists. Assumes monotonic increase.)

This is Milad...I think there are unique challenges faced by scientists dealing with legacy programs. For example, often times the codes perform calculations using very complicated physics/mathematical models. So not only do you face the standard set of legacy code issues, but you also have a kind of legacy physics issue...

Also, here is an article from nature that was sent to me a while ago: http://www.nature.com/news/2010/101013/full/467775a.html  It describes some of the more "political" consequences of using a lot of legacy code in science. Greg Wilson is quoted a few times.
scientists are not programers: nosetests, source control, test cases, sample runs, not enough comments.
in science, many short terms grad students
